item.title: It’s Always Market Day Somewhere
item.dc:creator: G.
item.description: There’s not much in this life I enjoy more than strolling and sniffing out the week’s new treasures at an open-air market, careening from one deceivingly innocuous stall to another, only to find each brimming with seasonal jewels from the land and the sea.  Market day, for me, is a colorful, remarkable and unabated pageant [...]

item.title: 15 years on and still learning the lingo
item.dc:creator: kba
item.description: Someone asked me at lunchtime today how long I had been living in Norway and unusually I was able to answer quite accurately, because in two weeks I will have been here for exactly 15 years (to those who know me, no, I can`t quite believe it either). In many ways time simply flies unaided, [...]
item.content:encoded:
Someone asked me at lunchtime today how long I had been living in Norway and unusually I was able to answer quite accurately, because in two weeks I will have been here for exactly 15 years (to those who know me, no, I can`t quite believe it either). In many ways time simply flies unaided, and, in others (such as the way my husband refuses to age), it is just an aspect to be dealt with only as and when it is painfully punctuated by reminders of physical decline.

To be honest though, whether I have lived here for 5, 10, 15 or 20 years is, to me, immaterial, as I´ve felt at home from day one.  This did all get me thinking though about my relationship with the Norwegian language and, while obviously a personal and highly subjective subject, a few things came to mind, which may or may not be useful to others in a similar situation.

There`s always someone going to be better than you
Although I have studied and learned languages for as long as I have had a curiosity about life in other countries, I know I will never be as tonally accurate, erudite or eloquent as others I could name (Marcelle, Halldor). However, the thing is, it doesn`t matter. I have English friends who are far better wordsmiths than I am and know even the odd Norwegian who has a very impressive knowledge of highly amusing, if a little dodgy, English urban slang. Basically a foreign language is a tool and a work in progress. The key, I would say, is just to persevere with the initial learning to get it to a level that works for you as quickly as you can, as this will make life easier and more relaxing in the long run. On down days too, it also helps to remember that actually not all the natives speak or write perfectly correctly either.

You won`t find all jokes funny
Another thing I have found is that humour is a touchy subject that doesn`t always translate well and is often a great source of embarrassment: either you get the joke but don`t think it`s funny; you don`t get the joke until a painful half an hour later and sometimes you will never never get it, even after someone has felt sorry for you and publically tried to explain it to you, step by painful step. On the other hand, thankfully a sense of humour often manages to transcend language so you may find yourself laughing at the gist, mannerisms and delivery, despite not being able to unravel the words.  The bottom line is, I would say, that we`ve all been there and we will all be there again – just hang on in there and sweat it out!

Not all days are the same
The last point I want to make is not to be worried if some days you have the true gift of the gab and can feel like you are speaking in tongues, as it were, and others when that tongue feels as furry as a parrot´s cage. I know that some days I can write something in Norwegian that appears impressively native while others I despair and am convinced I should go back to square one. I like to think this is normal. As long as you have continuous improvement at the back of your mind (note I don`t mention timescales) and you accept that a good grasp of grammar is important, you`ll get there in the end.

So how do you know when you are fluent?
Well technically, of course, it is when you can express yourself accurately at roughly the same speed as you would in your mother tongue and with an idiomatically correct figure of speech. In real life, I would say that it`s when you find yourself happy to gently chastise (OK, shout at) your husband, dog, cat, mirror, in your new adopted tongue, because let`s face it, your brain here will be telling you to use whichever tongue is most likely to get the desired effect. You never know, given that your other half is probably the one who taught you those words in the first place, they might even feel quite proud!

item.title: Album Review: Feist Metals
item.dc:creator: Eric Walters
item.description: It doesn’t take long for Metals to grasp your attention. From the opening drum line the record, folk pop singer-songwriter Leslie Feist’s third, takes hold of you and doesn’t let go. The mood here is more somber than her previous releases as the record is teeming with minor chords, dark imagery, and morose lyricism, all [...]
item.content:encoded:
It doesn’t take long for Metals to grasp your attention. From the opening drum line the record, folk pop singer-songwriter Leslie Feist’s third, takes hold of you and doesn’t let go. The mood here is more somber than her previous releases as the record is teeming with minor chords, dark imagery, and morose lyricism, all to great effect. There are no moments of head bopping pop, such as The Reminder’s smash hit “1234,” but the album doesn’t need it. This is a different voice from Feist, and one that’s just as intriguing and entertaining as anything else she’s done. The lyricism at work can be both direct and vague, telling a story of apparent heartbreak, desire to escape, and ultimately to “get it right,” the “it” being left up to the listener to determine. “A good man, a good woman, can’t find the good in each other/ A good man and a good woman will bring out the worst in the other/ The bad in each other,” Feist sings on “The Bad in Each Other.” The entire record is filled with heartbreaking moments such as this, taken from the chorus of the opening track. These words and the undeniably beautiful voice expressing them is what drives the record.

It’s no secret that Leslie Feist has incredible vocal ability and she is in top form on Metals. A sign of a great vocalist is one who can force you to pay attention, distract you from whatever you are doing, causing you to close your eyes and just listen. There are numerous moments here in which Feist forces you to pay attention with her arresting voice. The best example of this is on the record’s most beautiful song, “Cicadas and Gulls.” The most stripped down track it consists only of a finger-picked guitar and overlaying vocals. These vocals are Feist’s alone and they are pushed to the front. They completely own the song, and completely own the listener as well.

In a recent interview with Pitchfork the singer admitted to taking a year, the longest break of her career, off from playing any music. Perhaps more artists should take extended breaks if it leads to music this beautiful.

Standouts- “The Bad in Each Other,” “The Circle Married the Line,” “Cicadas and Gulls”

Grade: A

item.title: Netflix backpedals on Qwikster change
item.dc:creator: Geoff Pickle
item.description: It looks like Qwikster simply will stay a funny, made-up word. Less than a month after announcing plans for the DVD-only change and a week after the printing of my column – “Is Netflix DVD move ahead of the curve?” – the company has backed out of its decision to transition the DVD portion of [...]
item.content:encoded:
It looks like Qwikster simply will stay a funny, made-up word.

Less than a month after announcing plans for the DVD-only change and a week after the printing of my column – “Is Netflix DVD move ahead of the curve?” – the company has backed out of its decision to transition the DVD portion of its business to Qwikster.com.

In an Oct. 10 blog post, Netflix Inc. CEO Reed Hastings seems to backpedal on earlier remarks he made that streaming and DVD services had become too different to keep on the same Web site.

The newest post is brief – unlike his Sept. 18 explanation of the need for Qwikster – and appears to show the mark of a company afraid of losing its subscriber base.

“It is clear that for many of our members two Web sites would make things more difficult, so we are going to keep Netflix as one place to go for streaming and DVDs,” Hastings wrote. “We value our members, and we are committed to making Netflix the best place to get movies and TV shows.”

And that’s about it as far as explanation.

Clearly, the fans spoke, and the company listened. We may never know how Netflix would have been affected had Qwikster become a reality. Though it is hardly befitting of a company to flip flop its decisions, if Netflix execs were worried enough about the service to not even go through with it, it’s probably better that it didn’t happen.

Despite this move, I’m sticking to my prediction that DVDs are on the way out. It appears, however, they won’t go down without a fight.


Filed under: Uncategorized Tagged: DVD, Netflix, Netflix Inc., Qwikster, Streaming

"The purpose of our lives is to be happy." Dalai Lama

I  chose this quote because balloons make me happy.  I did the maze because I wanted to play with multiple colors and I thought the balloons were a great way to do it.

item.title: Film Review: Real Steel
item.dc:creator: Sverrir
item.description: A robot boxing movie from the director of both Night at the Museum films, the Pink Panther remake and Cheaper by the Dozen. You’d be forgiven for thinking it would turn out offensively bad, but you’ll be surprised by Real Steel. Completely surprised. Hugh Jackman is a deadbeat, down on his luck jackass former boxer out [...]
item.content:encoded:
A robot boxing movie from the director of both Night at the Museum films, the Pink Panther remake and Cheaper by the Dozen. You’d be forgiven for thinking it would turn out offensively bad, but you’ll be surprised by Real Steel. Completely surprised.

Hugh Jackman is a deadbeat, down on his luck jackass former boxer out to make a quick buck in the robot boxing world of 2020. He comes into custody of his son (Dakota Goyo) through rather sleazy, but hilarious, means. That, of course, sends him on the road to redemption. It’s the classic underdog story on multiple levels. A kind of Rocky, if it also featured a robot fighting its way up the ladder.

Jackman is his usual charming self, putting in a truly great performance. His relationship with his on-screen son is entirely believable. They share great character moments and have brilliant chemistry. Goyo holds up his end, he’s pretty darn good. His character has real backbone and is clearly his father’s son. Both also have a great relationship with the robot Atom, despite the fact that he’s remote-controlled. He works as a device for them to project themselves and their feelings on to.

Evangeline Lilly as a robot grease monkey, gym owner and daughter of Jackman’s former boxing coach rounds out the trio of charisma in the film. She’s spunky and holds her own next to Jackman and Goyo. It also doesn’t hurt that Lily is a stunningly beautiful woman, she should really feature in more films.

Outside of the core three, there’s pretty much only ham and cheese (Anthony Mackie & Kevin Durand deliver that in a positive way, though). The dialogue and delivery by the support players is noticeably inferior, especially for the antagonists, Olga Fonda and Karl Yune. They’re nothing more than cardboard cutouts with barely a whisper of back story or motivation, rather reminiscent of 80s villains, actually. Thankfully, not too much screen time is devoted to them.

The story is well paced and never feels like it’s killing time until the next story beat, its full run time (127 minutes) runs without a single dead spot. The film simply draws you in and constantly entertains.

Shawn Levy shows that he’s capable of so much better with this film. He’s obviously helped by his main cast, the weakness of the side characters is a weakness of the script rather than the directing.

The film features some nice cinematography and editing, with a few inspired uses of focus and numerous wide shots that go on longer than one has come to expect from a robot action movie. Speaking of which, the fight scenes, of which there are many, are well choreographed and thankfully feature steady camera work, giving you the optimal view at all times. Those scenes are downright fun to watch.

Additionally, the production design is fantastic. The crew does well to build a convincing world of the near future of 2020. Little touches, like phone technology and how screens have evolved, make sense. The film does well to never shove these things in your face. The robots look great. Made with a blend of animatronics and special effects, they exude character and attitude, emoting convincingly, despite not speaking. Danny Elfman‘s score is almost completely anonymous until the climax, where he, like the film itself, kicks things into emotional high gear.

Final Verdict: Fun and entertaining, leaving you with a smile on your face. Real Steel could easily have been so much worse, but Jackman, Goyo and Lily elevate the material and make the film worthwhile. It features an amazing climax that’ll have you cheering and possibly even tearing up. A reprieve from the incoming wave of seriousness in the form of Oscar contenders. And yes, there’s a montage.

Review: Sverrir Sigfusson

@Sveppi and @Filmophilia

item.title: Beer Battered Fried Pickles
item.dc:creator: Christina
item.description: We continue onto Week 6 of College Football, which means another delicious Football bite! This week I give you one of my favorite guilty pleasures-fried pickles! Nothing says let’s watch some football more than beer battered pickles. I remember the first time I tried fried pickles was in my hometown of Columbus, Ohio at The Old Bag of [...]
item.content:encoded:
We continue onto Week 6 of College Football, which means another delicious Football bite! This week I give you one of my favorite guilty pleasures-fried pickles! Nothing says let’s watch some football more than beer battered pickles. I remember the first time I tried fried pickles was in my hometown of Columbus, Ohio at The Old Bag of Nails Pub. I about fell out of my chair! Warm, crunchy, beer battered pickles served with a ranch dipping sauce-I was in heaven! I know some of you that have not tried fried pickles think I am crazy for posting this recipe today, but for those of you that have tried them, I bet you are already making plans to try these! Trust me, you need these at your next tailgate! So go ahead and pour yourself a cold one and sink your teeth into some incredible pickles!

One Year Ago: Dark Chocolate Cupcakes with Peanut Butter Frosting 

Beer Battered Fried Pickles

Printer Friendly Version

Ingredients:

  • 2 (16-oz.) jars dill pickle spears, drained
  • 1 large egg
  • 1 (12-oz.) bottle beer
  • 1 tablespoon baking powder
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • Pinch cracked black pepper
  • Pinch cayenne
  • 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
  • Vegetable oil
  • Ranch for dipping

Directions:

  1. Place pickles in a fine mesh strainer set over a bowl to drain for 10 minutes. Than pat pickles dry with paper towels.
  2. In a large bowl, whisk together the egg, beer, baking powder, salt, pepper, and cayenne. Add the flour and whisk until smooth.
  3. In a large sauce pan, pour oil to a depth of 1 1/2 inches and heat over medium-high heat to 375°.
  4. Dip pickle spears into batter and fry in batches, 3 to 4 minutes or until golden. Drain paper towels and serve immediately with ranch dipping sauce.

Yields: 8-10 servings

Source: adapted from Southern Living, July 2007

If you’ve missed them, make sure to check out the rest of my College Football Bites: 

Week One: Pizza Pretzel Bites               

Week Two: Slow Roasted Pulled Pork 

Week Three: Mini Corn Dogs                 

Week Four: Buffalo Chicken Bites         

Week Five: Texas Chili

media:content.media:title: Dark Chocolate Cupcakes with Peanut Butter Frosting

item.title: St. Louis Arch – Gateway to the West
item.dc:creator: sallymontana
item.description: Pretty impressive building that is. For all the architecture lovers out there, the Gateway Arch was designed by Eero Saarinen in 1947, built in the 1960′s and is 630ft /192m high. Likes! Filed under: free works, job assignments, miscellaneous, private life
item.content:encoded:
Pretty impressive building that is. For all the architecture lovers out there, the Gateway Arch was designed by Eero Saarinen in 1947, built in the 1960′s and is 630ft /192m high. Likes!


Filed under: free works, job assignments, miscellaneous, private life
